nodes.text: Clinical trials must be managed according to standards for sponsors
Clinical trials must be managed according to standards for sponsor-investigators
An Institutional Review Board must oversee clinical trials
Medical institutions must follow standards for conducting clinical trials
Investigators must follow standards for conducting clinical trials
Informed consent must be obtained from clinical trial subjects
Standards must be followed for documents submitted in reexamination
Clinical trials must ensure scientific quality
Clinical trial data must be reliable
Clinical trials must protect the rights of human subjects
Clinical trials must ensure the safety of human subjects
Clinical trials must promote the welfare of human subjects
Post-marketing clinical studies must be conducted at medical institutions
Clinical trial investigators must be physicians or dentists
A coordinating committee must be composed of multiple physicians or dentists
The sponsor or sponsor-investigator must assign coordination duties to the coordinating committee
Monitoring must oversee the progress of a clinical trial or post-marketing clinical study
Monitoring must determine compliance with the Ministerial Ordinance and protocol
Monitoring must be performed on medical institutions by the sponsor or appointed individual
A single protocol must be used for multi-site clinical trials
A coordinating investigator must submit clinical trial notifications on behalf of all participating investigators
A sponsor-investigator must submit a clinical trial notification to conduct a trial at their institution
An investigational product provider must supply investigational products to sponsor-investigators
Expanded clinical trials should be conducted with a humanitarian perspective
Specific documents must be submitted for product applications as specified in Article 14 of the PMD Act
Collect and generate relevant data in compliance with specified chapters and sections of the Act
Prepare written operating procedures for duties related to sponsoring and managing clinical trials
Include protocol preparation in written operating procedures
Include selection of medical institutions and investigators in operating procedures
Include control and accountability of drugs used in the clinical trial in operating procedures
Include collection of information on adverse drug reactions in operating procedures
Sponsors shall secure professionals with adequate expertise to fulfill clinical trial duties
Sponsors shall complete studies on quality, toxicity and pharmacological effects of the test drug
Sponsors shall select medical institutions meeting qualifications in Article 35
Sponsors shall select investigators meeting qualifications in Article 42
Sponsors shall prepare a clinical trial protocol
Protocol should include name and address of the sponsor
Include name and country of residence for persons outside Japan in clinical trial documentation
Provide name and address of in-country representative for non-Japanese residents
Document name, address and scope of duties for any outsourced clinical trial contractors
Include names and addresses of all medical institutions involved in the clinical trial
List names and titles of all appointed investigators
State the objectives of the clinical trial
Provide a summary of the drug used in the clinical trial
Document the clinical trial design
Protocol must state reasons for enrolling subjects unable to give consent
Protocol should explain how subject disadvantages are minimized
Protocol must state if subjects unable to consent will be enrolled
Protocol should explain intent to seek marketing approval for emergency use
Protocol should explain current treatments are likely insufficient
Protocol should explain possibility of saving subject's life with test drug
Protocol must note establishment of Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee
Sponsors may submit documents using electronic data processing systems with consent
Electronic submissions must use specified electromagnetic means
Sponsor's computer must connect to medical institution's computer via telecommunication line
Information must be transmitted from sponsor's computer to medical institution's computer
Transmitted information must be recorded in a file on the recipient's computer
Sponsors may make information accessible to medical institution via computer file
Medical institution must record accessed information in a file on their computer
Sponsors must notify medical institutions of their decision to accept electronic document transmission
Electronic documents must be securely stored on magnetic disk, CD-ROM, or other storage media
Medical institutions must be able to print out electronically stored data
Sponsors must inform medical institutions of the type and description of electromagnetic means used
Sponsors must obtain written or electronic consent from medical institutions for electronic communication
Sponsors must specify the file format used for electronic communication
Sponsors must cease electronic communication if notified of its unacceptability by medical institutions
Sponsor must make trial information accessible to contractor via computer file
Contractor must record trial information in their computer file
Trial information may be delivered via secure storage media (magnetic disk, CD-ROM)
Information sharing method must allow printing of recorded data
Method must confirm information has not been modified
Sponsor shall inform contractor before concluding contract
The contract must specify the name(s) and address(es) of the medical institution(s)
The contract must specify the name(s) and title(s) of the person(s) in charge from each party
The contract must specify the name(s) of the investigator(s)
The contract must specify the duration of the clinical trial
The contract must describe the control/accountability of drugs used in the trial
The contract must describe record and data keeping procedures
The contract must describe maintenance of subject confidentiality
The contract must describe compensation to subjects for trial-related injuries
The protocol should explain that the test drug is intended for emergency life-saving treatment
The protocol should explain that current treatments are unlikely to be sufficient for the subject
The protocol should explain the possibility of saving the subject's life using the test drug
The protocol must note that an Efficacy and Safety Assessment Committee has been established
The sponsor-investigator shall revise the protocol when important new information becomes available
The sponsor-investigator shall prepare an Investigator's Brochure with specified information
Sponsor-investigator must have an audit plan for related duties
Sponsor-investigator must maintain a list of prospective subinvestigators
Document explaining drug control/accountability in clinical trial must be provided
Document explaining compensation for trial-related injuries must be provided
Medical institution must provide sponsor-investigator access to trial records upon request
Sponsor-investigator may terminate trial if institution violates ordinance or protocol
Contract must be concluded when outsourcing clinical trial duties
Sponsor shall prepare documents explaining reconstitution procedures for investigational products
Sponsor shall deliver reconstitution procedure documents to investigators and other specified personnel
Provisions of Article 10 Paragraphs 2-5 apply to delivery of operating procedures in Paragraph 6
Provisions of Article 10 Paragraphs 2-5 apply to delivery of documents in Paragraph 7
Sponsor shall supply investigational products manufactured at adequately equipped sites
Manufacturing sites must have adequate buildings and facilities to ensure product quality
Sponsors shall immediately notify investigators and medical institution heads of relevant facts
Sponsors shall revise protocol and Investigator's Brochure when aware of relevant new information
Sponsors shall obtain investigator consent for protocol revisions
Sponsors shall prepare written procedures for monitoring
Monitoring shall be conducted by visiting medical institutions
Monitors shall immediately notify investigators of compliance issues
Monitors shall submit monitoring reports to sponsors after each visit or communication
Sponsors must prepare an audit plan for clinical trials
Sponsors shall prepare written operating procedures for audit-related duties
Audits must be conducted according to the audit plan and operating procedures
Auditors must be independent of drug development and monitoring divisions
Auditors shall prepare an audit report documenting the audit findings
Auditors must prepare an audit certificate verifying the audit has been conducted
Sponsors must terminate trials at institutions violating regulations or protocols
Sponsors shall promptly notify relevant parties if a trial is suspended or terminated
Sponsor must notify medical institutions in writing of clinical trial suspension or termination reasons
Sponsor must notify medical institutions if clinical data won't be included in regulatory application
Sponsor shall prepare clinical trial reports summarizing results when trial is completed or terminated
Sponsor shall retain all records related to the clinical trial
Records must be retained until later of marketing approval or date specified in regulations
Sponsors must retain protocol documents for 3 years after trial completion
Sponsors must retain contracts for 3 years after trial completion
Sponsors must retain clinical trial reports for 3 years after trial completion
Sponsors must retain case report forms for 3 years after trial completion
Sponsors must retain monitoring records for 3 years after trial completion
Sponsors must retain audit records for 3 years after trial completion
Foreign sponsors must have in-country representatives retain specified records
Indicate 'For clinical trial use only' on investigational product containers/packages in Japanese
Include sponsor-investigator name and address on investigational product containers/packages
Include chemical name or ID code on investigational product containers/packages
Include manufacturing number/code on investigational product containers/packages
Include storage and expiration information on containers/packages if necessary
Do not indicate proposed brand name on investigational products or packaging
Do not indicate proposed indications on investigational products or packaging
Enable subinvestigators to identify test drug from comparator in emergencies
Investigational products must be manufactured at sites with adequate buildings and facilities
Manufacturing sites must have appropriate manufacturing control systems
Manufacturing sites must have appropriate quality control systems
For expanded trials, drugs may be selected from medical institution stocks
Investigational product containers must be labeled in Japanese with required information
Investigational products must be managed separately from other drugs
Sponsor-investigator may assign coordination duties to a coordinating investigator or committee
Sponsor-investigators must retain the protocol for clinical trials
Sponsor-investigators must retain approval documents for clinical trials
Sponsor-investigators must retain clinical trial reports
Sponsor-investigators must retain case report forms
Sponsor-investigators must retain records of monitoring and audits
The head of a medical institution shall establish an Institutional Review Board
The IRB must review whether it is appropriate to conduct the clinical trial
An IRB may be established by an academic society of healthcare professionals
An Incorporated Educational Institution with a medical institution may establish an IRB
An Incorporated Administrative Agency providing medical care may establish an IRB
An Incorporated National University with a medical institution may establish an IRB
A Local Incorporated Administrative Agency with a medical institution may establish an IRB
The IRB founder shall include IRB establishment provisions in their incorporation articles
The IRB must include at least one healthcare professional
No more than 1/3 of IRB directors can be employees of a certain medical institution
The IRB founder must have sufficient financial basis to operate adequately
The IRB founder shall retain and provide public access to financial documents
The IRB must be capable of reviewing trials from ethical and scientific viewpoints
The IRB must be composed of at least five members
The IRB must include member(s) without expertise in medicine/healthcare
IRB must include members independent of the medical institution
IRB must include members independent of the IRB founder
IRB founder shall prepare written operating procedures
IRB founder shall disclose operating procedures, member list, and meeting summaries
IRB founder shall appoint person(s) to perform clerical work
IRB members with close ties to sponsor shall not participate in related deliberations
Members who have not participated in the IRB deliberation shall not vote
The head of the medical institution shall seek the IRB's opinion on trial appropriateness
A written contract must be concluded with external IRBs before reviews
IRB contracts must specify the date of conclusion
IRB contracts must specify names and addresses of the institution and IRB founder
IRB contracts must specify procedures for contract-related operations
IRB contracts must specify the due date for the IRB to give its opinion
IRB contracts must include description of maintaining subject confidentiality
The head of the medical institution shall obtain the IRB's written operating procedures
The head of the medical institution shall obtain the IRB's list of members
The head of the medical institution shall seek the IRB's opinion on continuing the trial annually
Annual IRB review is required when trial duration exceeds one year
The head of the medical institution shall seek expert IRB opinion on specialized matters
Head of medical institution must seek IRB opinion on continuing trial when receiving reports per Article 48 or 54
Head of medical institution may seek expert IRB opinion on specialized matters for continuing trial
Paragraph 5 of preceding article applies to cases where expert IRB opinion is sought
Head of medical institution must seek IRB opinion upon receiving monitoring report per Article 26-8
Head of medical institution must seek IRB opinion upon receiving audit report per Article 26-9
IRB opinion must be sought on whether trial is being or has been conducted properly at the institution
Expert IRB shall review specialized matters for determining appropriateness of continuing clinical trial
Each IRB shall provide opinions promptly in writing according to urgency of matters consulted
IRB shall review if clinical trial is being conducted properly at medical institution
IRB shall give opinion in writing on proper conduct of clinical trial
Head of medical institution shall notify sponsor and investigator of IRB opinion in writing
Head of medical institution shall notify sponsor-investigator of IRB opinion in writing
Medical institutions shall not undertake a clinical trial if the IRB deems it inappropriate
Medical institutions shall cancel or terminate trials if the IRB deems continuation inappropriate
Heads of medical institutions shall take measures if IRB finds trial not conducted properly
IRB founders shall retain written operating procedures
IRB founders shall retain the list of IRB members
IRB founders shall retain records of meetings and summaries
The head of the medical institution shall take measures to protect subject confidentiality
The head of the medical institution shall cooperate with monitoring conducted by the sponsor
The head of the medical institution shall cooperate with audits conducted by the sponsor
The head of the medical institution shall cooperate with reviews by the IRB
The head of the medical institution shall provide direct access to clinical trial records upon request
The head of the medical institution shall appoint person(s) to perform trial-related clerical work
The investigational product storage manager shall properly control/account for drugs used in clinical trials
The storage manager must comply with operating procedures stipulated in Article 16 or 26-2
Medical institutions must contract with outsourced duty providers via a document specifying required information
Outsourcing contracts must specify the scope of duties outsourced
Outsourcing contracts must describe operating procedures for outsourced duties
Outsourcing contracts must allow medical institutions to verify proper conduct of outsourced duties
Outsourcing contracts must describe instructions to the contractor
Head of medical institution must notify IRB in writing when sponsor reports trial termination
Head of medical institution must notify investigator in writing of trial suspension/termination
Head of medical institution must notify IRB in writing of trial suspension/termination
Head of medical institution must notify IRB in writing if data won't be included in application
Head of medical institution must notify IRB in writing if investigator suspends/terminates trial
Head of medical institution must notify sponsor if investigator suspends/terminates trial
Head of medical institution must notify IRB when investigator reports trial completion
Head of medical institution must notify sponsor when investigator reports trial completion
Investigators must keep records of control and accountability of drugs used in the clinical trial
Investigators must have education, training, and clinical experience to conduct the trial properly
Investigators must be well-versed in the trial protocol and Investigator's Brochure
Investigators must have sufficient time to conduct the clinical trial
Investigators must prepare a list of duties assigned to subinvestigators and clinical research coordinators
Investigators must explain trial duties to subinvestigators and clinical research coordinators
Investigators must provide necessary information to subinvestigators and coordinators for proper conduct of duties
Investigators shall conduct the clinical trial in compliance with the IRB-approved protocol
Investigators shall document all deviations from the protocol
Investigators shall immediately submit protocol deviation documents to the sponsor and medical institution head
Investigators shall prepare CRFs accurately in compliance with the protocol
Investigators shall affix their name to CRFs
Changes to CRFs shall be dated and affixed with the investigator's name
Investigators shall inspect CRFs prepared by subinvestigators and confirm the content
Investigator shall submit written summary of clinical trial status to head of medical institution
Investigator shall immediately report death or serious adverse events to head of medical institution
Investigator shall notify sponsor of death or serious adverse events in sponsor-initiated trials
Investigator shall provide additional information on adverse events upon request
Investigator shall notify other investigators of death/serious events in multi-site investigator-initiated trials
Investigator shall notify investigational product provider of death/serious events in investigator-initiated trials
Investigator shall promptly notify subjects if clinical trial is suspended or terminated
Investigator shall provide appropriate medical care to subjects if trial is suspended/terminated
Investigator shall promptly report trial suspension/termination in writing to head of medical institution
Investigator shall report trial completion in writing to head of medical institution
Investigator shall submit written summary of trial outcome to head of medical institution
Investigators shall obtain written informed consent from subjects before trial participation
Investigators shall explain trial information in writing to subjects before obtaining consent
Legally acceptable representative may give consent for subjects incapable of consenting
Prepare records of consent from subject's legally acceptable representative
Document relationship of legally acceptable representative to subject
Do not enroll subjects incapable of consent if no clinical benefit is anticipated
Allow prospective subjects to inquire about trial information
Answer all subject inquiries about the trial satisfactorily
Provide written information to subjects including trial objectives
Include investigator name and contact information in written information
Describe alternative procedures or courses of treatment to subjects
Inform subjects of the duration of their participation in the clinical trial
Inform subjects they may withdraw from the clinical trial at any time
Inform subjects that withdrawal does not cause any disadvantage to them
Allow monitors, auditors, and IRB direct access to source documents
Keep subject identity confidential when allowing access to source documents
Provide contact information for the medical institution to subjects
Articles 4-6 apply mutatis mutandis to data collection for post-marketing clinical studies
Article 7 (excluding Item 1 of Paragraph 3) applies to post-marketing clinical studies
Articles 9-15 apply mutatis mutandis to post-marketing clinical studies
Articles 16-23 apply mutatis mutandis to post-marketing clinical studies
The term 'clinical trial' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study'
The term 'protocol' shall be read as 'post-marketing protocol'
The term 'investigator' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study investigator'
The term 'subinvestigator' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study subinvestigator'
The term 'sponsor' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study sponsor'
The term 'IRB' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study IRB'
The term 'investigational products' shall be read as 'post-marketing clinical study drugs'
The phrase 'all or any of' in Article 7, Paragraph 1, Item (2) shall be read as 'any of'
The 'date of submission' shall be read as the date designated by the Minister when granting marketing approval
'Investigator's Brochure' shall be read as 'instructions for use or Information on Precautions'
'Immediately notify the investigator' shall be read as 'immediately notify the post-marketing clinical study investigator'
'Protocol and Investigator's Brochure' shall be read as 'post-marketing protocol'
Records must be kept for 5 years after completion of reexamination or reevaluation
Retain clinical trial records until completion of reexamination or reevaluation
Use post-marketing protocol instead of protocol and Investigator's Brochure
Apply specified provisions mutatis mutandis to standards under PMD Act Article 80-2
Control and account for drugs used in clinical trials
Collect information on adverse drug reactions in clinical trials
Keep records related to clinical trial management
Obtain informed consent from the subject appropriately
Submit clinical trial protocols by June 30, 1997 for certain sponsor-initiated trials
Apply modified regulatory requirements for trials submitted by June 30, 1997
Submit clinical trial protocols by March 31, 1998 for certain sponsor-initiated trials
Apply modified regulatory requirements for trials submitted by March 31, 1998
Article 3 shall be read with specific modifications to referenced articles and paragraphs
Documents for reexamination must comply with modified Article 56 references for certain post-marketing studies
Modified Article 56 references apply to post-marketing clinical studies requested by June 30, 1997
"Paragraph 3, Item (1)" shall be read as "Paragraph 1, Item (9) and Paragraph 3, Item (1)" in modified Article 56
"Articles 11 through 16" shall be read with specific exclusions in modified Article 56
"Article 23" shall be read as "Article 20" in modified Article 56
MHW Ordinance No. 29 of 1997 shall apply to sponsoring clinical trials under Article 80-2, Paragraph 1 of the PMD Act
For certain 1997 trials, 'Item (9)' shall be read instead of 'Items (11) and (13)' in Article 57
For certain 1997-1998 trials, 'Item (11)' shall be read instead of 'Items (11) and (13)' in Article 57
Article 30, Paragraph 1 shall apply to persons conducting sponsor-initiated clinical trials under Article 80-2, Paragraph 4
Article 35 shall apply to persons conducting sponsor-initiated clinical trials under Article 80-2, Paragraph 4
Article 44 shall apply to persons conducting sponsor-initiated clinical trials under Article 80-2, Paragraph 4
Article 47, Paragraph 1 shall apply to persons conducting sponsor-initiated clinical trials under Article 80-2, Paragraph 4
Article 50, Paragraphs 1 and 2 shall apply to persons conducting sponsor-initiated clinical trials under Article 80-2, Paragraph 4
Obtain informed consent from subjects by appropriately explaining
Apply Article 27 to certain sponsor-initiated clinical trials conducted April-June 1997
Apply Articles 28-35, 38, 40-50, 51, 52 to certain trials conducted April-June 1997
Apply Article 27 to certain sponsor-initiated trials conducted July 1997-March 1998
Apply Articles 28-35, 38-50, 51, 52 to certain trials conducted July 1997-March 1998
Clinical trial protocols must conform to Article 7, Paragraph 1 provisions
Former Ordinance Article 67 applies to clinical trial management under certain conditions
Specific reading modifications apply to Article 59 for trials between April 1 and June 30, 1997
Different reading modifications apply to Article 59 for trials between July 1, 1997 and March 31, 1998
Sponsors must comply with modified interpretations of regulations during specified time periods
Protocols must meet provisions of Article 7, Paragraphs 1-3 of the GCP Ordinance
Protocols must meet provisions of Article 15-4, Paragraphs 1-3 of the GCP Ordinance
Post-marketing study protocols must meet provisions of Article 7, Paragraphs 1-3 of the GCP Ordinance
The Ministerial Ordinance shall come into effect from April 1, 2008
Specific revised provisions shall come into effect from April 1, 2009
Sponsors may apply the New Ordinance for Enforcement provisions to reporting at their discretion
Article 273, Paragraph 3 of the New Ordinance applies to sponsor reporting from July 1, 2014
Article 273, Paragraph 3 applies to sponsor-investigator reporting for trials starting after this Ordinance
Sponsor-investigator reporting before July 1, 2014 follows the previous Ordinance
Sponsors may optionally apply the New Ordinance to reporting before July 1, 2014
Previous provisions apply to notifications until June 30, 2014
Sponsors must notify authorities of clinical trials with protocols prepared before this Ordinance
Sponsors may apply New GCP Ordinance Article 20 Paragraph 2 to notifications made by June 30, 2014
New GCP Ordinance Article 20 Paragraph 2 applies to sponsor notifications from July 1, 2014
New GCP Ordinance applies to trials with protocols prepared after Ordinance implementation
Notifications made by June 30, 2014 are subject to previous GCP Ordinance rules
The Ministerial Ordinance shall come into effect on the promulgation date of Revised Act No. 47 of 2022
Provisions of Article 1, Item (2) of supplementary provisions to the Revised Act take effect August 1, 2021
MHLW Ordinance No. 84 of May 20, 2022 contains supplementary provisions
